Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the assertion that March 2020 was the first March without a school shooting since 2002.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there have been school shootings in every March since 2002, which is not supported by consistent data or definitions of school shootings.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were actually eight school shootings in March 2020, according to one key government database.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on inconsistent definitions and tracking methods of school shootings across government agencies, news media, and researchers.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the absence of school shootings in March 2020, which is the widespread school closures due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
